column1: Cabo San Lucas (Spanish pronunciation: [ˈkaβo san ˈlukas]
column2: "Saint Luke Cape")
column3: or simply Cabo
column4: is a resort city at the southern tip of the Baja California Peninsula
column5: in the Mexican state of Baja California Sur. As of 2015
column6: the population of the city was 81
column7: 111 inhabitants. Cabo San Lucas together with San José del Cabo is known as Los Cabos. Together they form a metropolitan area of 305
column8: 983 inhabitants.Rated as one of Mexico's top 5 tourist destinations
column9: Cabo is known for its beaches
column12: the sea arch El Arco de Cabo San Lucas
column13: and marine life. The Los Cabos Corridor has become a heavily trafficked vacation destination for tourists
column14: with numerous resorts and timeshares along the coast between Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo.

column1: The waters around Cabo are home to marine wildlife including rays
column2: sharks
column3: mahi-mahi (dorado) and striped marlin.

column1: Archaeological excavations have shown evidence of continual human habitation in the area for at least 10
column2: 000 years. When the first Europeans arrived
column3: they encountered the Pericú people
column4: who survived on a subsistence diet based on hunting and gathering seeds
column7: and other marine resources. They called the location Yenecamú.

column1: According to the narrative of Hatsutaro
column2: a Japanese castaway
column3: in the book Kaigai Ibun (written by Maekawa
column4: Junzo and Bunzo Sakai and narrated by Hatsutaro)
column5: when he arrived at Cabo San Lucas in May 1842
column6: there were only two houses and about 20 inhabitants. However
column7: American authors such as Henry Edwards and John Ross Browne claim that Cabo San Lucas's founder was an Englishman named Thomas "Old Tom" Ritchie. John Ross Browne says Ritchie arrived there about 1828
column8: while Edwards says that he died in October 1874.

column1: The actual founder of Cabo San Lucas was Cipriano Ceseña in 1788 who arrived from Hermosillo
column2: Sonora. Per The book by Pablo L. Martinez
column3: Guia Familiar de Baja California 1700–1900.

column1: A fishing village began growing in the area. In 1917
column2: an American company built a floating platform to catch tuna
column3: and ten years later founded Compañía de Productos Marinos S.A. The plant operated for several years.

column1: Cabo San Lucas has become a prominent vacation and spa destination
column2: with a variety of sites of interest and timeshares that have been built on the coast between San Lucas and San José del Cabo. The distinctive Arco de Cabo San Lucas is a local landmark.

column1: Cabo San Lucas has the highest paying marlin tournament in the world called the "Bisbee's Los Cabos Offshore". This tournament takes place every year in the month of October.In the winter

column3: and sport fishing opportunities in Cabo San Lucas have attracted a great number of Mexican natives and foreigners to spend their vacations in large-scale tourist developments there. The development of Cabo's tourism industry was prompted by the Mexican government's development of infrastructure to turn Cabo San Lucas into a major center for tourism in Mexico
column4: beginning in 1974. Upon completion of the Transpeninsular Highway
column5: also known as the Mexican Federal Highway 1
column6: tourist developments in Los Cabos proceeded relatively unchecked.

column2: the unique and fragile environment of this part of Mexico was largely unprotected by law
column3: and therefore was subjected to developers acting in concert with government agencies interested only in low-end tourist bonanzas. There is
column5: a growing collection of activists and attorneys now involved in preserving many of Baja's desert habitats
column7: and stretches of coastline. A number of agencies including the Gulf of California Conservation Fund and the Center for Environmental Law in La Paz are challenging the destruction of wetlands and other ecosystems from Los Cabos to Ensenada. In the face of a growing international public demand for corporate-driven ecological stewardship
column8: higher-end resorts in the Los Cabos area are increasingly sensitive to their environmental impact
column9: and are taking initial steps to institute sustainable practices such as reducing water usage and non-recyclable trash output. In 2017
column10: Los Cabos is projected to be one of the leaders in travel in Latin America
column11: many of the developments owed to its increased accessibility with added plane routes from the US and Canada. It is expected that by 2018
column13: 000 new sleeping rooms will come online in Cabo
column14: and the increase in tourism will contribute to its growth as a leader in leisure.

column1: Cabo San Lucas and San José del Cabo are served by Los Cabos International Airport.
The town is also a popular port of call for many cruise ships. Cabo San Lucas has a small international airfield
column2: which handles air traffic for general aviation flights and air taxi service.

column1: Many tourists get around the area through the numerous local taxis that service the primary parts of Cabo
column2: as well as the Corridor and the airport. Alternatively
column3: there is a system of small buses that are used by locals but also available to tourists
column4: and costing a few pesos tend to be much less expensive than the taxis.

column1: The extreme south of Baja California has a tropical desert climate (Köppen: BWh). Even with the thermal amplitude there are no freezes.During summer
column2: Cabo San Lucas is cooler than San José del Cabo by about 1.5 to 3 °C (3 to 5 °F).  Sometimes during the summer
column3: when winds blow from the Pacific Ocean instead of the Gulf of California
column4: the differences in temperatures between San José del Cabo and Cabo San Lucas are higher.

column1: Cabo San Lucas is less rainy than San José del Cabo
column2: although hurricanes can bring heavy rain for long periods. Hurricane Odile made landfall at Cabo San Lucas on 14 September 2014
column3: and caused widespread damage. Due to the position of the city and orography
column4: local summer thunderstorms do not get near enough to bring rain to the town.

column1: The sea temperature experiences lows of 21–22 °C (70–72 °F) in winter
column2: and highs of 28–29 °C (82–84 °F) during the summer months.

column1: The majority of non-Mexican inhabitants in the community originate from the United States
